text: I suspect the, I'm not sure I understand your question, but I suspect the answer has to do with whose point of view we're talking about.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you are the system that's in, so let's fix a Markov blanket someplace.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you're the system on the inside, then all you can see is what's encoded on the blanket.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And you have no independent access to what the dynamics is on the outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you don't actually know what the dynamics is on the outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And similarly, if you're on the outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, if you're somehow able to view the whole system, you can see the whole system as having some joint dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But if the whole system is isolated, then there isn't anybody on the outside, kind of by definition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the idea of a whole dynamics is just a theoretical postulate that we make to make the mathematics make sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, if you move from the classical formulation to the quantum formulation, then it's possible to prove a very nice theorem, which is that if you're inside a holographic screen, you can't measure the entanglement entropy across the screen.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What that means is that you can't know that your state is conditionally independent of what's going on outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you're inside a holographic screen, you can't know that you're not entangled with whatever's outside.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So you can't even know whether you have a well-defined state, in a sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I think the same thing would probably hold true from the point of view inside a Markov blanket, that you wouldn't be able to know whether your Markov blanket had holes in it or something like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I mean, the problem is in the classical formulation, you assume there's no analog of entanglement.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there's no analog of entanglement entropy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I think the strongest thing you can say is you don't actually know your statistical relationship to what's going on outside, but you still can only see what's encoded on the blanket.
